Wait a minute. Wait a minute. Wait a... And her brooch.
Yeah !
I wonder what Mary's doing now ?
Hey, you're telling me !
Do you still want me to wait here ?
Yeah. Okay, okay !
Hey, cab !... Here you are.
Yeah, that's right. I can go faster that way. Sure.
Wait a minute ! What am I doing ? Hey !
Come here !
Hey, you. Five more bucks and you'll own it.
Yeah ! I'm losing dough every minute. Got me offers ?
I knew this would end up in a nuthouse !
Hey !
Hey ! You'll own two cabs !
I mean the meter !
Oh, Mortimer.
Yes, love.
But, Mister Brewster !
I'm not a cabdriver. I'm a coffeepot !
I read an ad here about a room to rent.
I understand you've got a room to rent.
Well, are you the lady of the house ?
My name's Gibbs.
I haven't got a home. I live in a hotel. Don't like it.
Haven't got any family.
Yeah.
Is there always this much noise ?
I'd really like to see the room. Well, I don't think I'll like it.
Never touch it.
Elderberry ?
I haven't tasted elderberry wine since I was a boy.
Thank you.
Have your own elderberry bushes ?
Well, skoal.
They... they're nuts !
Mr. Witherspoon speaking... Oh, how do you do, Mister Brewster ? How are you ?

Oh, dear. Oh, dear. Oh, that's too bad. Well, I'd hoped we wouldn't have him for some time yet. Well, you see, Mister Brewster, we have several Theodore Roosevelts at the moment, and it would lead to trouble. Oh, trouble... Oh, now, if he thought that... Look, Mr. Brewster, we're a bit short of Napoleons at present. The Bonaparte. And if...
Another Roosevelt. Oh, dear, dear.
Yes, Mr. Brewster, yes.
Well, I don't understand you.
By the way, you've had the papers signed by your brother and the doctor, of course ?
Is your cab engaged ?
I'm Mister Witherspoon of Happy Dale Sanitarium, I have come here to collect a Brewster. I would like you to drive us back to the sanitarium.
We like to think of it as a rest home.
Mister Brewster ? Mister Brewster ?
Mr. Witherspoon is here.
Best of care of him, Mister Brewster.
Why ? To take him away ? Oh, never, never. Taxicabs. We always... I have one waiting now.
He'll be very happy at Happy Dale.
You know, I sometimes envy some of our patients, secretly, you know.
You never can tell.
Oh, this is a particularly happy moment for me tonight, Mister... Mister Brewster. Yes, I've never met a dramatic critic and I had been so anxious to.
I have here something that will explain what we're trying to do out there at Happy Dale.
Oh, no-no, it's a play. Something I've been working on for some time now.
It's a dramatization of many of the little incidents that have happened here at Happy Dale.
Now, I want you to read this very carefully. I want you to be just as harsh as you like. I shan't mind, you know...
Oh, yes, yes, he'll be very happy at Happy Dale. Come, my boy.
The police ?... Oh !
Happy man.
Oh, dear. And Happy Dale is full of staircases.
Oh well now, indeed, it's sweet of them to want to go, but it's quite impossible. We never take sane people at Happy Dale.
Oh, no-no-no-no...
Oh, no-no-no-no...
Oh, no ! No, no ! No ! Too dangerous. Dissension, jealousy.
Just the ladies ?
Well, of course, they'd have to be committed.
Well, Teddy committed himself. Couldn't they commit themselves also ? All they have to do is sign the papers.
Certainly.
I have them, ladies, I have them right here.
Ladies, if you will sign right here.
Yes, please. It's on the right-hand side right there.
Oh... oh, dear, I'm so sorry. We've overlooked something.
A doctor ?
It's all right, Lieutenant Rooney. The doctor here has completed the signatures.
Now, Mister Witherspoon...
It's contagious, yes. It's your turn.
You sign. You sign as next of kin.
Spoon.
Duffel ?
Oh !
Come in, doctor.
This is the home of my youth. As a boy, I couldn't wait to escape from this house. Now I'm glad to escape back into it.
The family must still live here. I hope there's a fatted calf awaiting the return of the prodigal.
As if we were expected.
A good omen.
Aunt Abby. Aunt Martha. It's Jonathan.
I'm Jonathan, you know. Your nephew, Jonathan.
I see you're still wearing the lovely garnet ring that Grandma Brewster bought in England. And you, Aunt Martha, still the high collar to hide the scar where Grandfather's acid burned you.
My face. Doctor Einstein is responsible for that. He's a plastic surgeon.
You see, doctor, what you've done to me ? Even my own family think I'm...
Bless you. It's good to be home again.
Don't waste any worry on that rat.
Forget Mr. Spenalzo.
We come to him for help and he tries to shake us down.
Tonight.
This time, I want the face of an absolute nonentity.
Be careful about the stitches this time.
You were careless last time.
Leave the eyes alone. Leave the nose alone.
My dear, sweet aunties, I'm so full of your delicious dinner I'm unable to move a muscle.
The cellar ?
Teddy ! I think it's time for you to go to bed.
I'm Woodrow Wilson. Go to bed.
General Goethals, inspect the canal.
Aunt Abby, I must correct your misapprehension. You talked of our hotel. We have no hotel. We came here directly.
Doctor Einstein and I need a place to sleep. You remember that, as a boy, I could be disagreeable. It would not be pleasant for any of us if... but I don't have to go into details, do I ?
Oh, I forgot to tell you, Doctor Einstein and I are turning Grandfather's laboratory into an operating room. We expect to be very busy.
What ?
Rather a good joke on my aunts. They're living in a house with a body buried in the cellar.

Yes, we can't just walk Mister Spenalzo in through the door. We'll bring the car up between the cemetery and the house, and after they've gone to bed, we'll bring Mister Spenalzo in through the window.
We're moving the car behind the house. You'd better get to bed.
I don't want to leave it in the street. That might be against the law.
We're bringing the luggage through here.
I'm afraid we don't keep Brooklyn hours. You two run along to bed.
It's time I came home to take care of you.
Take the bags upstairs.
Now, we'll all go to bed.
Run along, Aunt Martha. Just off the laboratory, Doctor.
All right, Aunt Abby.
Now, Aunt Abby ! Turn out the lights.
Aunt Abby.
I'll open the window. You go round and hand him through.
All right. We must be quick. I'll take a look around outside the house. When I tap on the glass, you open the window.
Be careful.
Who are you ?
What are you doing here ?
Why did you say your name was Harper ?
Doctor !
We happen to live here.
Perhaps we'd better introduce ourselves. May I present Doctor Einstein ?
A surgeon of great distinction. And something of a magician.
I am Jonathan Brewster.
You've heard of me ?
What do they say about me ?
Why do you come here at this time of night ?
You thought you saw someone drive up ?
You saw someone at the car ?
What else did you see ?
I see. Is that why you came over here ?
You've given two names.
I think she's dangerous.
Doctor, the cellar.
We caught a burglar, a sneak thief. Go back to your room.
I'll handle this. Go back to your room.
Do you hear me ?
Don't answer that.
Don't answer that !
I've come back home, Mortimer.
I've come back home, Mortimer.
Yes, I talk. Mortimer, have you forgotten the things I used to do to you when you were tied to the bedpost ? The needles under your fingernails.
I'm glad you remember, Mortimer.
Mortimer, you know what I do to people who order me around.
What ?
Doctor, you know, Doctor, I've completely lost track of Mister Spenalzo.
I'll take care of you, Mortimer, in just a little while.
This may interest you, Mortimer. I've decided that we're staying. And I've also decided that you're leaving, and I mean now.
I've led a strange life, Mortimer.
Don't reach for the telephone. Remember, what happened to Mister Spenalzo can happen to you, too.
Put down that telephone, Mortimer.
I don't think so.
Mortimer...
Doctor, this affair between my brother and myself has got to be settled.
We're not going. We're going to sleep right here in this house.
That's all he's got on us. We'll take Spenalzo and dump him in the bay. After that, we're coming back here. Then if he tries to interfere...
Doctor, we've got a wonderful setup here. We can make a fortune. Two old ladies as a front. Only Mortimer stands in our way. I never did like Mortimer.
Doctor, you know when I make up my mind...
Take the instruments and hide them in the cellar. Move fast.
What's the matter ?
Yes.
Yes, Mortimer.
We're not going.
No.
Now, if you tell O'Hara what's in the window-seat, I'll tell him what's down in the cellar.
There's an elderly gentleman down there who seems to be very dead.
Now what are you going to tell O'Hara ?
Why don't you both go down in the cellar ?
Where are you going ?
We'll wait for him.
Perish the thought, dear aunties. That was just Mortimer.
There's a friend of Mortimer's downstairs waiting for him.
Take his feet, Doctor. Mister Spenalzo and he will get along fine together. They're both dead.
You know about what's down there ?
But Mister Hoskins ?
Crowded ? With what ?
Twelve graves.
You mean that you and Aunt Martha have murdered twelve...
You've done all that right here in this house and buried them in the cellar ?
What ?
I've got thirteen.
Thirteen.
There's Mister Spenalzo. Then the first one in London.
Two in Johannesburg, one in Sydney, one in Melbourne, two in San Francisco, one in Phoenix, Arizona.
The filling station.
Three in Chicago and one in South Bend. That makes thirteen.
He wouldn't have died of pneumonia if I hadn't shot him.
Aunt Abby, go to bed !
You're forgetting, Doctor.
My brother, Mortimer.
I just heard him upstairs.
You are going to operate tomorrow, Doctor. But tonight we are taking care of Mortimer.

Replies.Reply: Look at me, Doctor. You can see that it's got to be done, can't you?
Replies.Didascalie: (voice over from the shadow on the wall)

Replies.Reply: It's a little late to dissolve our partnership.

Replies.Reply: Yes, Mortimer. I've been away for twenty years. But never, my dear brother, were you out of my mind.
In Melbourne one night, I dreamt of you.
The more you struggle, Mortimer, the more you strangle yourself. Later on, you may consider that a blessing.
Now, Doctor, we go to work.
Doctor, this must be an artistic achievement.
After all, we're performing before a very distinguished critic.
Doctor !
Pull yourself together, Doctor.
Doctor. One moment, please. Where are your manners ?
Yes, Mortimer. I realize now that it was you who brought me back to Brooklyn. We drink to you. Doctor ! To my dear, dead brother.
That idiot ! He goes next. That's all. He goes next !
We'll get to him later.
Now, we have to work fast. The quick way.
It's all right, Officer. We're taking the bugle away from him.
So I've been turned in, hey ? All right, you've got me. I suppose you and my stool-pigeon brother will split the reward.
Yes, reward ! Now I'll do some turning in !
You think my aunts are sweet, charming old ladies, don't you ? Well, there's thirteen bodies buried in the cellar !
I'll show them to you.
You come down to the cellar.
Now, wait a minute.
Thirteen bodies. I'll show you where they're buried.
Yes, come to the cellar.
I'll get every one of you ! I hate cops. I'll brain the first one that comes near me !
Yes, Johnny, it's a good hideout.
A fatted calf ? Oh, Johnny, I'm so hungry.
Look, Johnny. Drink.
Yes.

Take it easy, Johnny. Take it easy. Don't worry. The last five years, I give him three different faces. I give him another one right away. That last face. I saw that picture, too, just before I operated. I was intoxicated.
Johnny, Johnny ! You are home in this lovely house.
You know how many times he tells me about... about Brooklyn, about this house, and about his aunts he loves so much ? They know you, Johnny. Please tell him so.
Well, Johnny, where do we go from here ? You know, Johnny, we got to think fast.
The police, they got pictures of that face. I got to operate on you right away. We got to find someplace. We got to find someplace for Mister Spenalzo, too.
But we got a hot stiff on our hands.
But, Johnny, we can't leave a dead body in the rumble seat.
No, please, Johnny, take it easy. We'll find some place and I'll fix you up right away.
Yes, tonight, but I have to eat first.
Yes, Johnny. I know exactly what I'm going to do.
You see, I'm going to take this piece here and lift it up...
You leave that up to me. I'll give you nice little ears and...
And new stitches. And on the eyes I'll do a Schmidt. That's my specialty. You see, I take it together like this...
Yes, it's nice here.
My, how I've changed !
Oh, maybe some other time, Mister President. Panama is a long ways off.
Yes, sir.
All right, Mister President, we go to Panama.
Oh !
Well, bon voyage !
Hey, Johnny, Johnny. Come here. Quick.
Hey, Johnny, down here, what do you think I find ?

The Panama Canal. And it just fits Mister Spenalzo. See the hole he's digging. Four feet wide, six feet long. He just fits ! You'd think he knew we were bringing Mister Spenalzo along. That's hospitality.
Hey, how do we get him in here ?
Hey, Johnny...
For the instruments, I'll come back later.
He's all right, Johnny.
But he's too heavy for me.
You go outside, Johnny, and push, and I'll stay here and pull. And then together we take him down to Panama. Huh ?
Yeah.
It's dark in here.
Where am I ? Oh, here I am.
Who left this open ?
Johnny ?
Okay, Johnny, wait a minute. Hand him over. Now I have him.
Oh, but his shoe came off. Help me, Johnny. He's so heavy.
Hey, Johnny, somebody's at the door. Go open, quick.
It's all right, Johnny. It's okay.
Mister Brewster ! We don't take up much room. Johnny can sleep on the sofa, and I'll sleep on the window-seat.
Hey, Johnny. Mister Spenalzo.
What's going to happen to Mister Spenalzo ?
We can't leave him here in the window-seat. Johnny ?
A friend of ours Johnny was looking for.
It's all right, Johnny. While we are packing, I'll tell you about him.
But, Johnny, we've got trouble enough as it is. Come, let's go.
What ? With a cop in the kitchen and Spenalzo in the window-seat ?
No, no, Johnny. No, please.
No, Johnny, please, take it easy. Please !
Yeah, I know, when you make up your mind, you lose your head. Look, Johnny, Brooklyn ain't a good setup for you.
Okay, Johnny. Okay !
Hey, Johnny, Johnny, come quick !
You know that hole in the cellar ?
Well, we got an ace in the hole.
No.
But what is he doing in the cellar ?
Did he look guilty !
Mister Hoskins ?
Your gentlemen ?
That's wonderful, Johnny !
We've been chased all over the world, and they stay right here in Brooklyn, and they do just as good as you do.
Yeah. You got twelve, they got twelve.
No, Johnny, twelve. Don't brag.
Yeah.
Phoenix ?
Filling st... Oh, yes.
You cannot count the one in South Bend. He died of pneumonia.
No, no, Johnny, you cannot count him. You got twelve, they got twelve. The old ladies is just as good as you are.
They are, are they ? That's easily taken care of. All I need is one more. That's all. Just one more. And I've a pretty good idea who it is.
This is all fixed up nice now. Nice and smooth like a lake.
Oh, Johnny, bed feels good already. You know, we didn't get any sleep for forty-eight hours.
What ?
No, no, no ! I am tired. You forget, I got to operate on your face tomorrow.
No, but Johnny, not tonight ! I'm sleepy. We'll do it tomorrow. Or the next day.
Yeah, I know that look.
Okay, okay, Johnny, okay. We'll do it. But the quick way, huh ? The quick twist like in London.
Not the Melbourne method, please ! Two hours ! And then when it was all over, what ? The fellow in London was just as dead as the fellow in Melbourne.
Hey, Mister Brewster.
Hey, Mister Brewster, you get out of this house.
Get out of here, will you, please ?
Johnny's in a bad mood. You get out of here !
Please listen to me. Get out.
I tell you later about that, but you go now. Please listen to me.
You get out of here ! Look, look, when Johnny's in that mood, he's a madman. He's a maniac ! And then things happen. Horrible things.
You get out of here !
Oh no ! My schnapps !
That's mine.
But, look, Mr. Brewster, please. You've just been married.
Tell me, don't those plays you see all the time teach you anything ?
At least people in plays act like they got sense.
How can somebody be so stupid ?
Yes.
Well, I don't know.
Oh, what ?
Curtain cord ? But didn't he see him get it ?
But what does he do ?
You were right about that fellow. He wasn't very bright.
Johnny, for me, please, the quick way. Please.
Please.
Johnny, please !
All right. Let's get it over with. No, but, Johnny, I cannot see this without a drink.
But I can't pull myself together without a drink. Johnny, you remember when we came in here, there was some wine. And then they took it. Where did they put it ?
Johnny, I found some wine. I found some wine.
Here, I'll split it with you. We both have a drink before we operate. Oh, I am so happy that we don't have to operate without a drink.
Prosit !
Not Teddy ! Not Teddy ! Please !
Not Teddy, we won't get to him at all !
Oh, the quick way, oh yes ! If it has to be, then the quick way. Yes, I'll help you with it.
Nothing. He was explaining a play he saw the other night and that's what happened to a poor man in the play.
Yeah, probably your play put him to sleep.
I personally, I like it very much.
Yeah.
No, please.
Hey, Johnny, the cops !
Good night.
Yes, please.
I don't think we go to the same place.
Poor Teddy. I imagine it's for the best.
Mortimer is very irritated by the Judge's erratic attitude. He puts a pen in his hand.
Sometimes I think, with the world in its present chaotic state...
Only last week I created a mild sensation at the Bar Association, when I said...
Tell Martha and Abby I'll be over this week. I've been feeling rather lonely.
Why, no. I never indulge.
Of course a little wine now...
I may be committing the wrong Brewster.
This is most irregular, most irregular.
I know Teddy blows bugles, but I can't commit a man to an institution just on that.
Who ?
Here ?
In the cemetery ?
It's Halloween.
Livingstone ?
Yes, indeed.
That's what you think.
Goodbye, Ambassador. I've enjoyed this little talk very much. Anytime you're in Washington, drop in to see me at the White House.
Those papers. Those papers.
I'll enjoy committing him to any place.
I've just been appointed Ambassador to Bolivia !
Do you have to tie him up to make him listen ?
He's got a gun...
Howdy, Colonel.
He's come to. He's ready to talk.
Yes, sir.
How about it, lieutenant ?
What has occurred ?
Well, we...
Never mind ! Didn't I tell you I'd handle this myself ?
What happened ? He put up a fight ?
Boris ?... Turn him over.

guys can't look at the circulars we put up in the station, you can at least read short detective stories. Certainly, he's wanted somewhere. In Indiana ! He escaped from the prison for criminally insane. He's a lifer.
Thirteen bodies buried in the cellar, and that don't tip you off the guy's come from a nuthouse ?
Where have you been all night ? Don't bother to tell me.
Yeah ?
Well, you're going to have a long time on that play.
You're suspended. Now go on. Report in.
Take this guy out in the kitchen and bring a pillow. I want to find out where his accomplice is.
The guy who helped him escape. He's wanted, too.
Forty-eight hours I've been after these guys. Nothing to eat. No sleep. No wonder Brooklyn's in the shape it's in.
Who are you ?
What the blazes is this ?
Well, Colonel, you've blown your last bugle.
Come on, get this guy out of here.
What ?
Take him out and bring him to. I want to question him.
Hey, you, keep out of that.
Who are you ? What's your name ?
Oh, you're his brother. Now, look, Mister Brewster, no argument. He's got to be put away.
Well, as long as he's going someplace. He's scaring the neighbors, what with that bugle and all. And that cockeyed story about thirteen bodies being buried...
You know, I've been without sleep for forty-eight hours.
There's people dumb enough to believe a story like that.
These papers are no good.
He signed it Theodore Roosevelt !
Hold him till I get there.
Hey, that's all right ! Do that again for me.
What is this?
I'm sure! Here are the papers, all signed. Now you can take him away, Super.
No, he's come to take him. Teddy's been blowing his bugle again.
I'm sorry.
Mister Brewster's got nothing to do with this, see. The law is the law ! Teddy's committed himself and he's got to go.
Now, let's be sensible, ladies...

...Here I am wasting my time when I could be doing some serious work. You know, ladies, there are still murders to be solved in Brooklyn. It ain't only his bugle blowing, and neighbors being afraid of him. But things are going to get worse. We're liable to have to dig up your cellar.
Yeah.
Yeah, Teddy's been telling around there's thirteen bodies buried in the cellar.
What ?
What is this ?
I'll be right there.
Well, right now I wouldn't know what is and what ain't strange anymore. I'll better have a look in that cellar.
Flowers ?

Your gentlemen ?

How about it, Super ?

What is all this ?
